qas.question: Who censured Kant for his agnostic tautology?
Along with Schopenhauer, whose idealism did Nietzsche attack?
Nietzsche's attack on Schopenhauer used an argument similar to Kant's attack on who?
What kind of error did Kant say Nietzsche's argument had?
Which two philosophers did Nietzsche agree with?
Who argued that Nietzsche's theory of the world was wrong?
What did Kant ridicule Nietzsche for?

context: <a0_0>Friedrich Nietzsche<a0_0/> argued that <b5_0>Kant<b5_0/> commits an <b3_0>agnostic tautology<b3_0/> and does not offer a satisfactory answer as to the source of a philosophical right to such-or-other metaphysical claims; he ridicules <b6_0>his pride<b6_0/> in tackling "the most difficult thing that could ever be undertaken on behalf of metaphysics." The famous "thing-in-itself" was called a product of philosophical habit, which seeks to introduce a grammatical subject: because wherever there is cognition, there must be a thing that is cognized and allegedly it must be added to ontology as a being (whereas, to Nietzsche, only the world as ever changing appearances can be assumed). Yet he attacks the idealism of <b4_0>Schopenhauer and <a1_0><a2_0><b7_0>Descartes<b7_0/><b4_0/><a2_0/><a1_0/> with an argument similar to Kant's critique of the latter (see above).
